title: 15 Minutes of Math Daily – Does It Actually Work?
description: The surprising effectiveness of short, consistent math practice vs. long sporadic sessions.

content.intro: When I started telling parents "just 15 minutes a day," they looked skeptical. "How can 15 minutes help when school does an hour?" Here's the science – and the results.

sections.text: Learning science is clear: distributed practice (short sessions over many days) beats massed practice (long sessions few times). This is called the "spacing effect" and it's one of the most robust findings in cognitive psychology.
Studies show students retain 50% more when the same total practice time is spread across many sessions vs. concentrated in few sessions.
A 7-year-old can deeply focus for about 14-21 minutes. After that, you're fighting biology. Better to stop before focus fades than push through diminishing returns.
Memory consolidation happens during sleep. Practice today, sleep, practice tomorrow = two consolidation cycles. Hour-long session = still just one cycle.
15 minutes every day becomes a habit. An hour occasionally stays an event. Habits require less willpower to maintain.
Short sessions end before frustration. Kids associate math with "quick and done" not "long and painful."

faq.question: What if 15 minutes isn't enough for homework?
faq.answer: 15 minutes is for skill-building practice. Homework is separate. But if practice is consistent, homework becomes faster over time.

faq.question: Can I do less than 15 minutes?
faq.answer: Yes! 10 minutes is great. Even 5 minutes daily beats nothing. Start with what's sustainable, build up.

faq.question: What if they want to continue past 15 minutes?
faq.answer: Let them! But don't require it. Ending while they still want more builds positive associations.
